utterances: You thought people were writing and criticizing your hard crossword puzzles?
Well, this is interesting because our winner has actually two connections to both your trip for your reunion as well as Yo Yo Ma.
First of all, we received about 1,400 entries - more than that actually, this week.
And our winner picked at random is Carl Courant from New York City.
I am very well this morning.
Number one: you were once on Jeopardy.
You were - and you did well?
Well, actually thrice on ""Jeopardy,"" so I did well twice and then crashed and burned the third time.
And the other thing - it's curious is to say Yo Yo Ma puzzle - you like to play the cello.
Oh no, I play in a community orchestra, the New York Repertory Orchestra, and play some chamber music among friends.
Well, New York City is a great place to find music to both hear and play.
But as far a playing Puzzle, are you ready?
I'm going to read you some sentences.
Each one conceals the name of a tree in consecutive letters somewhere inside it.
For example, if I said use soap please, you would say apple, because apple is hidden in consecutive letters inside soap please.
And you can do these without writing down, I'm confident.
Number two: tomorrow I'll own the company.
The agency pressed for more money.
School officials must give them lockers.
Rich Lowry is the editor of the National Review.
He talked to us from our studios in New York.
Thanks so much for being with us, Rich.
Coming up: recalling legendary football coach Eddie Robinson.
First, the big political news today: money and a lot of it.
For Senator Barack Obama, his campaign raised $25 million during the first three months of this year to fund his presidential bid.
That's almost as much as the 26 million announced earlier this week by his top rival, Senator Hillary Clinton.
We're joined by John Dickerson, who's chief political correspondent for the online magazine, Slate.
Twenty-five million dollars for Barack Obama?
They are a surprise, and the - a number of things are a surprise here.

The big number is a surprise, the 25 million, also the idea that it was raised from 100,000 people is also a surprise, and it's kind of amazing and it has people really just blown away in the political community as e-mails go around and people talk about what Obama's been able to do here.
His home paper, the Chicago Tribune, has a piece on this today citing this 100,000 number, noting that Senator Clinton raised money from 50,000 people.
And the paper went in to a lot of detail about how Senator Obama did this.
A lot of action on the Internet.
There is a lot of action on the Internet.
One of the things we're all trying to figure out is - and there are a couple of other things that Obama did here.
He took his events - took smaller amounts in checks than the Clinton campaign.
He raised money mostly for the primary.
The Clinton campaign raised a lot for both the primary and the general election.

We don't know how much of the money, the 26 million raised by Hillary Clinton, goes to the general election, but it looks very much like it might be possible that Obama raised more in a shorter period of time with a less well-established fundraising system than Clinton had, which in some ways now makes him the frontrunner.
